* Amendment No. (9), standing in the names of Mr. P. Selvadurai, Madam Chan Choy Siong, and Mr. Ho See Beng, reads as follows:

    Head 0901 -

    Madam Chan Choy Siong (Delta)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I was saying yesterday that in 1959 the People's Action Party announced its policy in a booklet entitled The Tasks Ahead. One of the main principles was the interests of the people. So I would like to touch on the labour policy of the Government to see whether the balance in the interests of labour is maintained. At that time it was announced in the booklet that the P.A.P. was the workers' movement and it had always received the support of the workers. The P.A.P. Government is a government on the workers' side. Although we recognize the limitations of our entrepot trade, our economy and the necessity for private capital and private enterprise, it is our duty to see that the workers get a fair return for their labour, without which capital would be barren and fruitless, and the wealth and prosperity which labour produces ---

    Mr Tang See Chim (Choa Chu Kang): On a point of order, Sir,I think this is now the time for consideration of Head 0902, and I hear the Member for Delta speaking on -

    The Chairman: No, Mr Tang. Under the revised times, we are still on the Ministry of Labour.

    Mr Tang See Chim: I am sorry.

Column: 824



    Madam Chan Choy Siong(In Mandarin): I was saying that the workers should get a reasonable share for their effort. Without this basic condition, even if we have the capital, entrepot trade and other facilities, the labouring class who produces the wealth will not get equal benefit, and there will not be a balance of interests. So if we want to be prosperous through industrialisation, hut we cannot succeed, it is because good working conditions and other benefits to the workers cannot be procured, and the workers will not get their rightful reward. The present situation, however, very clearly tells the people of Singapore that the P.A.P. Government is looking after them well. Ever since we the P.A.P. came to power, we have all along abided by these tenets or promises which we have made to our electorate up to now.

    If we re-examine our present declared policy, we will find that perhaps the Government thinks that because Singapore has achieved independence it can lose sight of this declaration that was made some time ago. Some workers have been neglected, especially workers in the Jurong industrial site. True, Singapore must industrialise in order to maintain the livelihood of its two million people, but very clearly we have this policy which says that we must achieve a balance of interests, in other words, we must look after the interests of capital as well as the interests of labour. If we examine the actual conditions of the workers in the Jurong industrial site, we will find that they have been exploited in their wages. The money given to them can be regarded only as an allowance and not as actual wages, because they, who have been producing goods for their employers, are only given meagre allowances, not even amounting to wages, if I can call it.

    I have also touched on this matter of wages earlier. Normally a worker gets $2.50 per day. But the answer given by the Minister is that this $2.50 is not

Column: 825

regarded as wages but as an allowance, because most of the workers are unmarried and this is a sort of allowance given to them. But after investigation, I found that it is not actually so. This sort of policy therefore actually contradicts the announced policy of the P.A.P. Government. If you regard these workers as apprentices, then it is not right. In the past I have tried to rectify this abnormal situation, but we can still find it going on in the Jurong industrial site. I have found that many of the workers who are getting $2.50 per day are actually married. The Minister has said that they are unmarried, but after my investigations, I have found that they are married with children. So this policy, in actual fact, contradicts the P.A.P. announced policy on labour. I feel that an erroneous conception has been so formed so that the employer looks down upon women labour.

    Another point is that when we say that we want to help the workers, we mean that the workers' unions concerned will look after their members. But many of the workers in Jurong do not join any union. Firstly, they get very low wages. They have to spend more than $1 a day when they travel to and from their places of work. For lunch they have to spend about $1 per day so that when they return home they have nothing left for their family if their wages are only $2.50 per day. Because of this, the workers do not join any trade union. Because of this, the employers exploit them so that all their claims have been ignored, especially the claims of women workers, like maternity benefit and medical care.

I think it is not quite true to say that female workers in factories in Jurong are getting a very low pay. According to the Sample Household Survey conducted in July 1966, the average monthly earnings of female workers of 18 years or above in all manufacturing industries were $100.80 cents a month.     Head 0902 -

    Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 0902 be reduced by $100.

    Sir, before I touch on the point I wish to raise on the Industrial Arbitration Courts, let me make it very clear that whatever I say in relation to the Industrial Arbitration Courts does not refer to the President, the Deputy President or any official of the First and Second Industrial Arbitration Courts. In fact, I would like to pay my tribute to the President and Deputy President of the Courts for their past work in handling the multifarious cases that have been presented in the First and Second Courts. But whatever point I raise to indicate the present state of affairs the parties concerned are now in, may I emphasise that it is not the fault of the courts but it is the fault of the system in operation that is to be blamed? The present method of having panel members from employee and employer groups does undoubtedly cause unwanted and unnecessary delay not only in hearings but also in the making of awards. Sir,

Column: 828

the Industrial Relations Ordinance lays down that the award shall be handed down within two weeks after the parties concerned have presented their arguments. The fact that no one in the Ministry of Labour or the Advocate-General's Chambers has queried why the Ordinance has not been followed indicates that all have accepted that this is not possible. Under the circumstances, I would like to ask the Minister if we are not defeating the very purpose for which the Industrial Arbitration Courts were set up. The policy of the Government was and, I hope, still is industrial peace with justice. But I ask, can we have industrial peace with justice if there are delays in handing down the awards which sometimes last for months and even more than a year after the cases have been heard? Of course, both the unions and the management may admit that they do have justice, but a rather belated justice. Meanwhile, there is frustration among the workers and this frustration must necessarily affect production, a matter with which, I am sure, all of us are concerned. I feel that something must be done to accelerate the hearings and the making of the awards of the cases by the courts. Have the Minister and his officials given thought to this matter? They may be very busily occupied with other matters. But, nevertheless, I would like to suggest this for the Minister's consideration and sincerely ask him to give his urgent attention to this matter. I suggest that the courts should have permanent panel members. In other words, either the members of the management and the employees should be engaged on a full-time basis, or do away with them completely and let all the cases be heard by either the President or the Deputy President only. My other suggestion is that the Minister appoints only panel members who can afford to spare the time. If a member, having been nominated to sit on the cases, finds himself unable to attend the hearings on, say, three consecutive occasions, he automatically disqualifies himself from hearing any further cases.

Column: 829



    The Chairman: Mr Ho, if you stop now, the Minister will have three minutes to reply.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Yes, Sir.

    Mr Jek Yeun Thong: I think, in short, the Member for Bras Basah has suggested that we do away with the panel members. I am not sure whether this is feasible because the panel members, whether they are employers or employees, are there to assist the President of the Industrial Arbitration Court to weigh the pros and cons in a given case and together they form the court. If we were to do away with the panel members, then the President would be left alone to make the decision, and since the decisions on the awards of the courts are not subject to appeal to any higher court, it may appear that the burden of the President in making his decision is too heavy as to be unbearable and at times he may be accused of bias or being arbitrary.

    Regarding the suggestion on the setting up of permanent panel members, I do not think it is possible because, firstly, it is not possible to get enough suitable persons from the trade unions and the employers' side to serve as permanent members in the panel, and, secondly, the cost of maintaining such a permanent panel would be quite prohibitive and, in some cases, it may not be economical to do so because for some periods of the year there may not be any case for the members to hear at all.

    The third suggestion put forward by the Member is that the Minister should appoint only panel members who cart afford to spare the time. If that is the case, I do not think this would be workable because nobody actually worth appointing as a panel member can actually spare the time, and in that case we would not have any panel members at all.

    The Chairman: Order. Mr Ho.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not very satisfied with the reply by the Minister. Although he has

criticised my suggestions, he has not offered any solution.

    Head 1001 -

    The Chairman: Let me say that there are four Members who have put down six amendments. There is a total of 25 minutes. With that reminder I call Mr Tay Boon Too.

    Mr Tay Boon Too (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1001 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1051.

    Sir, the building of a rugged and brave next generation is one of the national policies of Singapore. This shows the farsightedness and the deep thought given by the Government of the Republic of Singapore. This policy is in keeping with the principles of nation building, that is, in order to build a strong nation, we must first have a strong and healthy people. However, there is a certain amount of dissatisfaction among sports circles in Singapore today with certain members in the National Sports Control Board. Mismanagement and the erroneous views of certain members on this Board have produced some bad consequences. The Government has been trying to promote sports in recent years. Towards that end, it has been trying to reorganise the sports organisations. However, certain members holding responsible positions in the Sports Control Board have behaved in a prejudicial manner. I feel that this behaviour should be corrected. In the past, the sporting activities in our country were under the management of the Singapore Olympic Council. But this year, as a successor to the Singapore Olympic Sports Council, there has

Column: 831

been established a body called the Singapore National Sports Control Board which manages all matters pertaining to sports. However, there are no experts on the Board who are conversant with the technique of volleyball and basketball matches. Sir, I would like to recount an incident. The recent SEAP Games were meant mainly to raise the standard of sports of certain countries in this region where the standards are low. Compared with some other international sports meets, the SEAP Games standard is the lowest. It is the lowest among all international sports meets.

3.00 p.m.

    So what kind of standard did we use to select our team members? Did we base our standard on the Olympic Games or the Asian Games? In what events of the Olympic Games did Singapore's contingents ever win any gold medals? If our sports teams are not sent abroad to compete in international games, how do we expect them to raise their sports standard? We will be just closing our eyes. The relevant authorities have said that the selections were based on quality and not on quan tity. Of course, I agree with this. But what is the quality required? Is it that the members selected should be up to the standard that they can expect to win gold medals? If that is so, then the selectors must have been very sure that the members selected for the SEAP Games must be people who had already reached the gold medal standard. But there were many members who got only zero back from the SEAP Games, especially the men's table tennis team. Since it was claimed that selection was based on quality and not on quantity, what happened to those teams selected to represent us at the SEAP Games who got zero marks back for Singapore? Were they affected by Thailand's sunny weather so that there was some sort of chemical reaction which changed their quality and which was different from what they had expected it to be? There is some suspicion that there was bias in selecting our contingent members.

Column: 832



    Sir, our volleyball team under the able leadership of our Minister of State of Defence had made much progress. They had been training since June last year. There were four collective training periods per week. There had been 200 such occasions totalling some 400 hours. This volleyball team can be said to be one of the most hard-working teams among our sports organisations. The women's team also improved greatly its standard. Recently at the match with the Malaysian women's volleyball team, the Singapore team defeated them 3 - 0. At the recent SEAP Games, the Malaysian women's volleyball team got the bronze medal. The Burmese team got the silver medal. The Burmese team defeated the Malaysian team 3 - 1. So judging from the standard of our team in April, our women's volleyball team's standard was not only higher than that of the Malaysian team, but was also higher than that of the Burmese team. They can be said to be a match for Thailand's women's volleyball team. Yet the selection committee said that our volleyball team -

    The Chairman: May I remind the Member that he has already spoken for ten minutes?

    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): Thank you, Sir, for your reminder. I have almost come to the end of my speech. Yet the selection committee said that the women's volleyball team had not reached the standard required. I should say that the committee concerned was actually behaving like a blind man groping for the tail of the elephant.

    Sir, there are 15 organisations under the Singapore Olympic Sports Council and the Secretary of the Council had very close relations with seven of the organisations. Recently, out of the 11 organisations which had members in the Singapore contingent to the SEAP Games, seven organisations were under him. I would like to ask how many gold, silver or bronze medals were gained by these seven organisations? How many got zero marks back? The idea of holding the SEAP Games, other than enabling all countries in South-east Asia to

Column: 833

take part in competition and raising the standard of sports, is also meant to improve the relationship among the participating countries.

    The sponsor country recently sent a delegation here specially to persuade our authorities to allow our volleyball team, basketball team, football team and rugby team to take part in the SEAP Games. Yet its request was rejected. Would it affect the relationship between Singapore and Thailand, especially in rugby? Rugby was proposed by our country to be added as an item in the SEAP Games and yet we did not send any rugby team to take part. What is past is past but for the future, we can still do something to rectify the situation. I hope the Minister can take some measures towards this end without fear or favour.

Member will accept my clarification in the true spirit of sports manship. I know why he is so interested in the reason why the basketball team was left out of the contingent. He is interested because he is the vice-president of the team.

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: I thought I had made myself very clear when the Sports Control Board announced its decision to exclude the volleyball team and, for that matter, the basketball team and two other teams from the Singapore SEAP Games contingent some time ago. As far back as August last year, I warned sports organisations in Singapore that unless they reorganised themselves and trained hard to achieve the standard required for inclusion in our contingent taking part in international sports meets, they would not be included.

    Mr Ho See Beng: You have not set any standard at all.

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: We have set a minimum standard for that. In the past, there was never a standard set by the S.O.S.C.

    Mr Ho See Beng: On what criterion?

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: Only a few sports organisations took heed of that warning. The rest did not care less. Even up to one month before the SEAP Games, the National Sports Control Board found that a number of sports organisations had not started training or had not trained seriously. The National Sports Control Board had decided on a certain required standard and sports organisations which wanted to be in cluded in our contingent should attain that standard. If they did not, then it was their own fault.

    Now, let us see what the basketball standard was. In the record that I have here, the standard of volleyball was generally very low. In the last SEAP Games in Kuala Lumpur in 1965, the men's team was placed seventh out of seven teams which took part. This means that they were the last in the competition. Burma beat them 3 - 0. Vietnam beat them 3 - 1. Cambodia beat them 3 - 0. Malaysia beat them 3 - 1.

To charge the Board of bias or prejudice is most unworthy of the critics. Even the organising council of the SEAP Games very sportingly accepted the decision of the Board after I had explained to them the reasons why our contingent was short of four teams. They commented that we had done the right thing, and one of the countries taking part in the Games was very interested in what we are doing to improve our standard and they asked us to send them all the information regarding the steps that we are taking.

    In conclusion, I would like to say that if the volleyball team want to be included in our next contingent to the SEAP Games or, for that matter, the Asian Games, they must improve their standard.

    An hon. Member: I hope the mistake will not be repeated.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Administration of Muslim Law Bill was introduced in Parliament in 1960 and re-introduced in 1965. Then it went to Select Committee which received representations from members of the public. Thereafter, it was brought back to Parliament for Third Reading and was passed in August 1966. It was assented to by the President in 1966.

    It is now six years since this Bill was introduced, but up to today it has not been put into operation although it has been passed.
